messages.message: You are now connected on Messenger.

Brian
Are you a scientologist?
I have another question for you too, collaborated with a friend of mine to come up with it.

Nate
Ha! Are you kidding me?
I'm an agnostic atheist! lol

Brian
But not scientologist?

Nate
Hell no!
I don't follow woo woo bullshit of any kind!

Brian
Ok, I think you'll like this one and help me improve it.  Here's my question.  On Earth, natural selection is a process where desirable traits in living things continue living, and undesirable traits are eventually purged from the species.  This is initiated from accidental changes to a species (e.g. a bird born with an unnaturally long beak, or a slightly different shade might be determined by mates as a good trait or a bad trait).

Brian
You follow me so far right?
Maybe I should word it better.

Nate
Yes
Got it

Brian
Here's the question, outside of natural selection on earth, is there a natural selection that occurs universally, and what would be the natural benefit of life?

Nate
Hmm. Interesting!

Brian
Ha!  Woohoo!

Nate
I'll make a post about it and tag you in it. How's that?

Brian
Sure lol

Nate
It's actually a fascinating question!
That is the type of stuff I lie in bed at night wondering about! lol

Brian
Man, took forever for me to come up with something that might stump them.  I've been a member of Atheist beings all year.

Nate
Thumbs Up Sign

Brian
Personally, I don't know how to describe my beliefs, I wasn't evading your questions earlier.  I believe Jesus existed, but I don't believe that believing in him is the only requirement for a happy life.  Some people find it to be enough.  I also don't believe that afterlife or death are the only options.  Any suggestions you have on that I'd be open to hearing.

Nate
Okay, we're getting somewhere. You believe that Jesus existed. Okay. Do you believe he was God? Divine? A prophet?

Brian
Yes, I believe those are all possible.  But that's not to say he was "supernatural".  Obviously prophecy can only be proven in hindsight with our current technology called "writing things down".
For example, if I am brainstorming all the possible times the arctic shelf could collapse, and I have been around the block.  If I guess precisely the day and time before it happens, it doesn't make me a prophet.

Nate
You say it's "possible". But, what do you actually believe to be true? Was Jesus God in the flesh? Yes or no? This is what determines whether you are a Theist or an atheist.

Brian
That's the other hard part.  I believe we are all part God.  So if I say yes, Jesus was God.  That still doesn't make him supernatural.

Nate
Any god is considered "supernatural" because he/she/it is not bound by nature, as humans are.
We must be clear that we are both using the same definition of "god".
If you are refferring to "god" as in "The Universe", then yes we are all a part of the Universe and therefore all a part of "god". Einstein used the term "god" in tbis sense.
That is called a "Pantheist". Someone who believes the entire universe to be what we call god.
But ... That is entirely different from the traditional and dictionary definition of the term "god". This definition is referring to a supernatural deity that is typically all-powerful or at least more powerful than humans. Those that believe in this definition are Theists.

Brian
Yeah, I read about Pantheism, it's kind of cool and makes sense.
But I think I found the root of the issue.  What you believe to be supernatural and what I believe to be supernatural are different.

Brian
I have seen too much not to share.  When I was in college I was wide-eyed, the world is my oyster, I have nothing to fear.  Last year, I was terrified, I lost my mind, went to therapy, and soon realized, I am still here.  Every day that I don't wake up with a headache is a miracle for me.  What I realized now is, when you take responsibility for other people outside yourself, it is both dangerous and mind-warping.  Your brain begins to think of longer and longer affects of your actions.  You piece things together in history that were never taught in history class.  Many people begin to experience this in their 20s and 30s, when they get married and have kids.  What I recently realized is, I am learning the same thing now, before the age that synaptic pruning takes place, what he learned in his 70s (he's an old minister).  That is, how to not live in fear.  Fear is the opposite of faith and they are mutually exclusive.

Brian
* used the word realized twice, that is a mistake, I should have said, my minister friend taught me how to articulate that last part about fear.
So, I ask you the same thing I asked him, he answered 1987 to 2016.  I said "When did you stop living in fear?"
Can you answer that?  I can give you an exact day that I stopped living in fear.

Nate
That's why it's important to know whether or not we are talking about the same thing.
That's why we have dictionaries, lol

Nate
Although, on a side note ... Dictionaries are written by fallible humans and are not authorities in and of themselves.
Dictionaries merely tell us how society uses words!
If someone wants to know the root of a word, he/she must do an etymological search.
Etymology is a fascinating study!
But, before we go on ... Let me try establish some basic information about your beliefs!

According to the dictionary definition of the term "god", would you say that Jesus was a god?
I don't think I agree that "fear is the opposite of faith. Faith is about beliefs. Fear is just an emotion. Totally unrelated.
Still trying to determine if you're a Theist or an atheist. It isn't really that hard! lol
If you believe in any type of dictionary definition of a god, then you are a Theist. If not, then you're an atheist.
Many Buddhists are atheists!

Brian
I'm not an atheist buddhism but I love the study and practice of buddhism, and I do study and practice.
Bible Gateway passage: Proverbs 8:17 - English Standard Version
I love those who love me, and those who seek me diligently find me.
biblegateway.com
Sorry link isn't related.
I agree with the last 3 definitions of god.
The 1st one about authority, as a scientist I must, by training, question everything including the righteous.

Nate
So, not the first 2 definitions?
If you don't believe the first two definitions, then it sounds like you're an atheist.

Brian
No, 2, 3, and 4
I agree with

Brian
Look, this is what my moral authority just told me: "I could spend (or waste?) a crap top of additional, precious time answering your questions and it would likely never change anything. You’re treating it like a heartless, curious thought experiment rather than taking anything I say to heart."  No wonder people argue about this shit, they can't even process their own damn beliefs.

Nate
There's only two possibilities: Theist or atheist. Everyone is either one or the other. There is no neutral zone.

Brian
But it's in the definition, it says (in certain other religions)

Nate
None of your last statement is even remotely true. It matters alot. I don't know you and explaining to me what you believe helps me to know you better. It's a real simple question and you have done a fantastic job of dodging it. None of the things you have said define what you believe. They are nice sentiments and I pretty much agree with them. But, so what? That still doesn't tell me what the hell you believe! LOL I just want to know if I'm talking to a Theist or an atheist. Very simple, bro!

Nate
Okay, so you say you believe in definitions 2, 3, 4. Looks like there is also a fifth. Anyhow, since you believe in #2, that makes you a Theist.

Brian
I believe God is a superhuman being or spirit worshiped as having power over nature or human fortunes; a deity.

Nate
FINALLY! Thank you! Then you are a Theist. Was that so hard? Haha!
You're right, it is a heartless question! It deals with the intellect, not the heart (emotions).

Brian
But I have tons of evidence.
I've been collecting.

Nate
The things you were saying regarding emotional matters are irrellevant to the intellectual discussion at hand.

People of various religions and even no religion can express deep emotional truths. That's great and all ... But, it doesn't tell me of you believe in a invisible sky daddy or not. 

Now, I know!

Nate
Evidence for a god? Is that what you mean?

Nate
If that is what you mean, then I would say that our emotions can deceive us. 

You probably don't know this about me, but I was in Christian ministry for 18 years. I studied Systematic Theology in Bible college. I preached on stage in church. I'm quite familiar with matters of the heart (emotions). I used to be a very strong believer.

Then, I started using critical thinking and tried to find empirical evidence for the god that I believed in. When I turned up empty handed, I had to be intellectually honest with myself. That's the day I became an atheist. Gods, deities, etc. are merely human concepts and there is no tangible evidence for these things.

Brian
To summarize, I think supernatural things happen all the time, and you think faith is the opposite of critical thinking?
What if I told you empathy help you learn to read minds?

Nate
What if I told you that the James Randi Foundation offered a one million dollar prize to anyone who can demonstrate supernatural abilities, this would include reading mindsb and no one ever claimed the prize?
Why didn't anyone ever claim the prize? Easy! Because supernatural abilities don't exist. There isn't any evidence that empathy helps read minds!

Brian
They died of heartbreak too soon, we didn't have the technology to track and prove it.

Nate
Sounds like you choose to believe things without scientific evidence! You're free to do as you wish as you wish, but I don't see it as very wise because it sets you up to fall for any ole scam out there!

Brian
This guy might be satan: 
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ja2NEfCEoJk
10 Of The Most Dramatic Derren Brown Moments
Relive, in no particular order, 10 of the most nail biting and, frankly, disturbing scenes from Derren's shows over the years. For more subscribe to our chan...
youtube.com

Nate
If something is unproven, there is no need to believe in it!
Wr must rely on evidence!
Deren Brown is awesome! He has exposed many, many scammers!
He and James Randi have both exposed psychic frauds!
See, this is why I wanted to know more about your beliefs. It reveals a lot about a person! I can clearly see that you choose to believe in woo woo for no apparent good reason.
Doesn't sound very scientific for a scientist (I think you called yourself that).
I'm sure you're a decent human being and all ... But, this isn't about that!

This is about beliefs and why people believe what they believe. 

Most of my atheist friends and I are also skeptics and we only believe things when evidence backs it up!

Brian
What if I had a test method to prove it, but it takes a lifetime to prove?

Nate
Then no one should believe in it until the time that it is proven. That's how science works!

Brian
But it will be too late for me.
Isn't that sad?

Nate
When the evidence is peer-reviewed and proven to be a fact, the whole world will know that it is true. Simple!

Brian
But what it was easier to test now, if someone believed me?

Nate
In my experience and observations, supernatural things always end up having a very natural explanation.

Brian
Ok, want one?

Nate
I find that most people who believe things without proof are quite gullible. Not always, but most of the time.
Go for it!
We really should be having this discussion on my Timeline, though.
Rather than private messaging.

Brian
When a person tries to take power over you: 
http://fortune.com/2017/11/29/libya-slave-trade/
There are certain ways to escape it: 
http://www.cracked.com/article_20504_the-5-most-badass-ways-people-escaped-from-slavery.html
Libya Slave Trade: What You Don't Know, But Should
An estimated 400,000 to 1 million migrants may now be trapped in Libya.
fortune.com
Prove to me that is not "superhuman"

Nate
You are privileged ... I rarely respind to private messages because I get so many, mostly from foreign people wanting money or wanting to save my soul. lol

Brian
Look how different is the language used in those two articles.  Both of them considered historically factual, but one of them uses mystical wording.
It's like a very real problem is downplayed using speech.  I believe this is all a part of a mass coordinated effort that only children of God could design.  Can process improvement be considered Godly?

Nate
I read both articles and did not see anything "superhuman". Many explanations could be provided and pysychic abilities isn't one of them. LOL
I don't need to "prove" that it's not superhuman. You first need to prove that it IS. The one making the claim always has the burden of proof.

Brian
Ok.  I'll collect more evidence.  It will take me some time, checkin next week / month?

Nate
Children of God? I don't believe in any gods, much less any "children of God". lol
Feel free
I always keep an open mind.

Brian
https://www.vanityfair.com/news/2016/08/peter-thiel-wants-to-inject-himself-with-young-peoples-blood
Peter Thiel Wants to Inject Himself With Young People’s Blood
The Silicon Valley billionaire reportedly sees blood transfusions as the pathway to radical life extension.
vanityfair.com
You said super human, that includes living longer than a normal human.

Nate
However, if you actually produce true evidence, I'll fucking send you 
$1000.00
!!! LOL

Brian
And my previously stated coordinated effort.  I just have to prove the coordination.
https://m.youtube.com/watch?v=PQynVVwlcSE
How a mathematician dissects a coincidence
Can you unknot a twist of fate with logic? Vox's Phil Edwards asked mathematician Joseph Mazur about his book, Fluke, and one of its most incredible stories....
youtube.com

Nate
That's not superhuman. No. That's doing something by a natural means.
Even the Marvel comic mutants in the X-Men series are not considered "superhuman". They have merely been genetically altered. Not the same thing!
Superhuman or supernatural would be something like the ability to fly without the use of machines. lol
Or to walk on water.
